subject: psu-ng: INPUT_HISTORY syncHistory
commitMessage:
psu-ng: INPUT_HISTORY syncHistory

Add in the function that syncs the power supply input history data
between all the installed power supplies.

Use the GPIO line name instead of gpiochip and number. Use libgpiod via
helper utility. Create a toggleLowHigh() to use for synchronizing the
input history.

Add in indicator and helper functions to indicate a syncHistory is
needed if a power supply goes from missing to present.

Trace when syncHistory is called. This should be infrequent enough that
I do not think it would be a problem.

Initial testing on Rainier 2S2U did not need a lengthy delay between
lowering and raising the power-ffs-sync-history GPIO, but testing on
Rainier 2S4u required a longer delay.

Depends-On: Ib1ac2456f7f715360d089dfa4b6b379b516439ab

Change-Id: I022806155139d70fb4a42cc27eb9f279f6a3aedc
Signed-off-by: Brandon Wyman <bjwyman@gmail.com>

Just out of curiosity, what is 'ffs' short for?
Do you want to sync all the remaining PSUs when one is removed?  Or is this only supposed to happen when a PSU is added?

The GPIO is OR'ed, it affects all the power supplies.

We only want to sync when one is added, as it will start out with no records, and the timing may not be in sync with the 30 second timer in the other power supplies.

That makes sense and is what I was suspecting.

In that case, this needs to go inside of an
  if (present)
?

Huh, yeah, it should, and it probably doesn't make a whole lot of sense to be calling setupInputHistory() when not present either, but it has a check.

I am starting to wonder why we have updateInventory() outside the presence check.
Replaced with syncHistoryRequired = true, moved down inside the present check.

Should this be using INPUT_HISTORY_SYNC_GPIO?  If not, what is the purpose of that meson option?

Also, is the assumption that all systems have this GPIO?  If not, how is that handled?  Is the meson option set to "", and then the lines above are not executed?

Yes, it should be using that INPUT_HISTORY_SYNC_GPIO from the meson option.

I was going with the assumption that it is only really supported if inputHistory (inputHistorySupported?) is true, which so far is only going to be set if the device driver is ibm-cffps.
I'm not sure what this comment means.  The *D-Bus* ObjectManager is located in the PSUManager, but the lines below are not doing anything related to that I think.
If this method effects all power supplies, should it be on the PSUManager class?
Perhaps I refactored this badly, but syncHistory() is no longer here. Replaced with indicator that sync is needed, and a helper to clear that it is needed.

See prior commit for CI failure:
[  FAILED  ] PowerSupplyTests.UpdateHistory (1001 ms)
Using meson options value as requested in power_supply.cpp review.
I think my lack of delay between the operations might be causing me grief in the power on case. I thought I saw this otherwise working, but perhaps it was a fluke.
This refactor worked really well IMO and makes more sense now.
Should be const?  Otherwise implies this is an output or input/output parameter.
True. I do not plan on modifying the delay and returning it back up.
As noted in another file, should be const?
Sorry, didn't spot missing doxygen in previous reviews.  Not a big deal, but probably should document these public methods.  Otherwise looks good.
Missing doxygen on this method and the next one.
